title: ASX dives; Flight Centre warns on profit
text:
Sarah Turner

Flight Centre said today that the trading environment has been relatively challenging and that first-half underlying profit would be below the same period a year ago.

Profit is likely to be heavily weighted toward the second half of fiscal 2020.

“Trading conditions and results deteriorated significantly in Australia, particularly within the leisure business, in November and December of 2018, and have remained subdued, meaning Q2 was likely to provide a more meaningful result comparison,” Flight Centre said.

Unrest and uncertainty have slowed profit growth in some geographies that have become material earnings contributors, it added. Examples included the UK and the US.

The firm expects increased costs early in fiscal 2020, after a new wage model and additional consultancy costs.

Lower than expected profits from emerging in-destination businesses are also a factor, as are lower interest earnings which reflects lower yields in Australia and higher interest repayments.

The firm will take $7 million costs after the collapse of Thomas Cook, associated with reaccommodating customers to ensure they were not affected by the collapse of Bentours and Tempo Holidays in Australia.

It added that online leisure sales had doubled in the country during the three months to September 30.

Flight Centre will release fiscal 2020 profit guidance at its annual general meeting on November 7.
description: Australian shares have fallen heavily at the open; Flight Centre warns on profit; Lazard's Aaron Binsted discusses the stock he's quietly excited about.
